title: Carolina Byl
text:
GIS Analyst and Environmental Engineer with 4+ years of experience delivering spatial analysis, cartographic products, and cloud-based geospatial solutions for environmental and infrastructure projects.
Proven background in enterprise geodatabases, remote sensing analysis using Google Earth Engine, and field data collection workflows.
Programming experience in Python, SQL, and JavaScript, applied to support multidisciplinary teams in national and international contexts, including technical instruction and mentoring.




You can find projects I’ve worked on in the “Projects” tab on this site.
I hope you can check out some of the projects I’ve worked on in this site.
You’re welcome to check out some of the projects I’ve worked on in this site.




BS & MS in Environmental Engineering @ Universidad Nacional de San Martín (UNSAM)
Diploma in Applied Geomatics @ Instituto de Altos Estudios Espaciales Mario Gulich (CONAE - UNC)

title: Hydrographic basins in Buenos Aires City
text:
Project Overview


This map shows watercourses of Buenos Aires, which are hidden in tunnels beneath the city. On the map, some of the drainage tunnels added in recent years are highlighted:

Vega Relief Tunnel — built to address the recurring floods in the Belgrano area.
Maldonado Relief Tunnel — also constructed to reduce flooding along Av. Juan B. Justo.
Cildañez Relief Tunnel — part of the Maldonado’s flow is diverted here so that the Cildañez never runs completely dry, helping prevent bad odors under the area of the Olympic Village built for the 2018 Youth Olympic Games (see picture).





Maldonado stream going into Cildañez stream.

title: Hydrographic basins in Buenos Aires City
text:
Data Sources and Tools

Watercourses and tunnels, hydrographic basins: IDECABA
Basemap: CARTO Voyager



Made with GIS 3.22.4-Białowieża

title: Contour lines for Pampa Linda, Río Negro, Argentina
text:
Project Overview


Pampa Linda is the main valley and nearest settlement at the base of Cerro Tronador. The mountain was named Tronador — Spanish for “Thunderer” — because of the sound of falling ice heard as one approaches the peak. It is the highest and most prominent mountain in Nahuel Huapi National Park, standing at 3,554 meters above sea level.




Tronador Mt. at Río Negro, Argentina

title: Contour lines for Pampa Linda, Río Negro, Argentina
text:
Data Sources and Tools

DEM SRTM with ~90m pixel resolution, obtained with OpenTopography DEM Downloader Plugin
Peaks, international boundary, settlements, water courses and bodies: National Geography Institute of Argentina



Made with GIS 3.22.4-Białowieża

title: London plane trees in Buenos Aires City
text:
Project Overview
London plane trees release their seeds in spring. Since they are so abundant in Buenos Aires City, the season is noticeable by almost everyone due to the annoyance of frequent sneezing and seeds getting into one’s eyes.






Platanus x hispanica leaves and fruits

title: Quality of Life Index
text:
Project Overview
As the final project for the Geographic Information Systems course in our Environmental Engineering degree, L. Sandri and I decided to analyze a region that is frequently studied across different subjects. Driven by the lack of detailed spatial data for the degraded Reconquista Basin, we focused on generating new insights for this specific area.
By replicating ACUMAR’s methodology, this study aims to generate comparable results and utilize cartographic visualization to identify vulnerable areas, ultimately providing a strategic tool for institutions to optimize resource allocation and design targeted socio-environmental policies.
Although we were unable to calculate the full index due to data limitations (specifically the environmental and education components), we successfully computed the housing and health metrics. This allowed us to perform a comparative analysis against the Matanza-Riachuelo index.

title: Quality of Life Index
text:
Data & Tools
All of the data was taken from public open sources:

INDEC: Housing characteristics and access to sanitary infrastructure was taking from the 2010 Census
Datos Abiertos de la Provincia de Buenos Aires: Distribution of public health institutions
Instituto Geográfico Nacional: Provincial and department political boundaries, water courses
Atlas de la Basura (FADU): Legal and illegal waste disposal sites (unavailable at the time of access)
All geospatial operations, and cartographic productions were done in GIS 3.14. Main tools used included native QGIS library for operations such as cut, dissolve, buffer, etc, and the use of the calculator to operate across layers.

title: Quality of Life Index
text:
Workflow

Calculations
The methodology followed the one proposed by ACUMAR [1] where:

QLI (Quality of Life Index) = 0.25 * HI + 0.25 * PHI + 0.25 EdI + 0.25 * EnI


HI: housing index
PHI: public health index
EdI: education index
EnI: environmental index

Because of the information available at the time, we were able to calculate both HI and PHI sub-indeces. When comparing with ACUMAR’s data from Matanza-Riachuelo basin, we only compared to those two, and using the same scale for visualization as the one proposed by ACUMAR.


Process

The fundamental spatial unit used was the “radio censal” (census radius), which is the smallest unit of geography used by INDEC for census reporting. All datasets with a coarser resolution were transformed to match this base layer, ensuring the analysis utilized the highest resolution available.
Although operations were performed for all census radii of all comprising departments of the Basin, for visualization purposes only those within the Basin were shown. This happens because a basin is defined by physical characteristics unlike political boundaries.






---
config:
  theme: base
  flowchart:
    padding: 5
---
flowchart TD
    C(Basin Boundary) -->|Crop| B(Mask) --> Y
    A(Water courses) -->|Crop| Y
    D(Census radii) --> |Selection of housing variables| E(Housing Index raw data) --> |Operations| F(Housing Index) --> Y
    G(Public health establishments) --> |Buffer, dissolve| H(Health Index)
    I(Static waste disposal map) --> |Digitalization from satellite images| J(Waste disposal locations) --> |Buffer and scoring by distance| H --> Y
    K(Political boundaries) --> Y([Join]) --> |Visualization| Z(Final cartographic product)
linkStyle default stroke:#40A355, stroke-width:2px;

title: Quality of Life Index
text:
Key Findings & Analysis




Quality of Life Index for Reconquista Basin compared with Matanza-Riachuelo Basin (only housing and health)



The methodology proposed by ACUMAR was successfully applied to the Reconquista River Basin to calculate Health and Housing indices, along with an adapted Quality of Life Index. The analysis focused exclusively on “urban” census radii, covering 27.91% of the basin’s surface area but representing 96.21% of the total population (2,942,680 inhabitants).
The study revealed that the vast majority of the population lives in vulnerable conditions: * Very High: 0.16% * High: 12.50% * Medium: 10.43% * Low: 37.04% * Very Low: 39.83%

Dimensional Analysis
The Health Index revealed widespread needs (driven by a lack of basic sanitary services), whereas the Housing Index showed generally better conditions with specific pockets requiring state intervention.


Spatial Findings

High QLI: Areas closest to CABA and high-density urban zones (often surrounding railway stations) showed the highest quality of life values.
Low QLI: Conversely, areas in close proximity to water bodies tended to have the lowest values.
Basin Distribution: No clear distinction was observed between the middle and lower basins in terms of QLI, though the middle basin presented more rural and mixed-use zones.

title: Quality of Life Index
text:
References
[1] ACUMAR, (2017a). Anexo III: Fichas metodológicas. Índice de Calidad de Vida (ICV). Available at: http://www.acumar.gob.ar/indicadores/indice-calidad-vida-icv/, on 19/08/2019.

title: Burn severity for Delta del Paraná, Argentina
text:
Project Overview

The wildfires in the Paraná Delta, Argentina - previously studied for Day 10 challenge - were brought up again to analyze from the point of view of its vegetation.
Sentinel-2 imagery was used in Google Earth Engine to calculate NDVI before and after the fire, highlighting the presence and condition of the vegetation immediately prior to and following the events. Using these NDVI values, dNBR was also computed, an index commonly used to estimate burn severity.
Negative NDVI values were masked and interpreted as water bodies or watercourses.

title: Burn severity for Delta del Paraná, Argentina
text:
Data Sources and Tools

ESA’s Harmonized Sentinel-2 (MSI) with Google Earth Engine
Province boundaries: National Geography Institute of Argentina
Basemap: Argenmap by National Geography Institute of Argentina



Made with GIS 3.22.4-Białowieża

title: Spatiotemporal visualization of urban growth in Tigre, Buenos Aires, Argentina
text:
Project Overview


For this map I compared the images from 1984 and 2011 from Tigre (Buenos Aires, Argentina), an area that underwent massive urban transformations.
During this period, numerous gated communities were built over former wetlands, altering the natural landscape with artificial lagoons and geometric layouts that sharply contrast with the original vegetation and terrain, which can be seen in the cartography.




Capybaras never left the wetlands even though they changed drastically





The band combination used highlights urban areas in pink and purple tones, vegetation in green, and water bodies in dark blue or black. These compositions help visually identify qualitative patterns and serve as a first step before applying quantitative methods, such as spectral indices.

title: Spatiotemporal visualization of urban growth in Tigre, Buenos Aires, Argentina
text:
Data Sources and Tools

Level 2 Landsat 5 images from July 1984 and August 2011.

SWIR (~2140 nm), NIR (~830 nm) and Red (~660 nm) bands were shown for RGB respectively.
The raster resolution is 30 m.




Made with GIS 3.22.4-Białowieża

title: Spatiotemporal visualization of urban growth in Tigre, Buenos Aires, Argentina

title: Carbon monoxide concentration in Delta del Paraná, Argentina
text:
Project Overview


Sentinel-5P (TROPOMI) dataset was used to visualize carbon monoxide (CO) levels over the Paraná Delta (Argentina) during the 2020 wildfires, compared with 2022 values.
Remote sensing, in this case, makes it possible to detect fires through atmospheric gases and helps us understand how these events affect not only ecosystems but also nearby cities and communities.




Firemen aiding at the wildfires in 2020.





This work was part of the course “Geostationary Satellites and their Applications to Hydrometeorology”, which I completed at the Gulich Institute (UNC–CONAE) in late 2024.

title: Carbon monoxide concentration in Delta del Paraná, Argentina
text:
Data Sources and Tools

ESA’s Sentinel-5P (TROPOMI) with Google Earth Engine
Province boundaries: National Geography Institute of Argentina
Basemap: Argenmap by National Geography Institute of Argentina



Made with GIS 3.22.4-Białowieża

title: My tour around Buenos Aires City
text:
Project Overview


The annual event “Vuelta en Bici a la Ciudad de Buenos Aires” consists of a mass tour of the city, departing counterclockwise from Parque Lezama. The ride is about 70 km long and takes between 10 to 12 hours to complete, with two fixed intermediate stops.
I used public transport to get to the starting point and to return, and I wanted to show that on this map as well. The symbols were chosen with accessibility in mind, ensuring the visualization does not rely solely on color.




Drone picture of bikers touring  Buenos Aires City, August 2023

title: My tour around Buenos Aires City
text:
Data Sources and Tools

My GPS Data retrieved with Google Maps and recovered using Timeline Viewer Map
Basemap: Argenmap by National Geography Institute of Argentina



Made with GIS 3.22.4-Białowieża
